title: Cryptomultiplier
author: Cryptomultiplier
content: Will the return of the gold standard prompt the rise or fall of Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies acceptance in general? Be it to be used as payment method or choice for liquidating or diversification of assets?Your thoughts are welcomed!

comments.author: FatFork
comments.body: Well, if that were to happen, I think there's a good chance more people might get into Bitcoin and crypto going forward.  But it's a double-edged sword - if gold becomes the primary place people put their money again, it could make Bitcoin less popular for a while.  Though that might just push developers to get creative and highlight what makes their projects one-of-a-kind.  So while gold could steal some Bitcoin's thunder in the short run, down the road it could find new ways to shine.

comments.author: DooMAD
comments.body: Highly doubtful there will ever be a return to the Gold Standard.  The world is still embracing neoliberal idiocy.  Those in power wouldn't be able to manipulate money in the way they're accustomed to if this were to change.  Ergo, it won't happen without some sort of mass global revolution.  The kind of thing with guillotines and no surviving billionaires.

comments.author: Fara Chan
comments.body: Quote from: Cryptomultiplier on July 28, 2024, 11:53:41 AMWill the return of the gold standard prompt the rise or fall of Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies acceptance in general? Be it to be used as payment method or choice for liquidating or diversification of assets?Your thoughts are welcomed!I don't think so, because if the return of the gold standard in general life will only affect the value of fiat in the eyes of many people, Bitcoin will continue to experience price increases as long as its acceptance is still widespread and I believe that Bitcoin's acceptance will not decrease when the gold standard is back among the world's people. And at this time I don't see gold as an opponent of Bitcoin because both can still have value and grow separately so that it will actually make it more difficult for fiat to determine its value in the future.

comments.author: Oshosondy
comments.body: Quote from: FatFork on July 28, 2024, 12:00:44 PMif gold becomes the primary place people put their money again, it could make Bitcoin less popular for a while.  Though that might just push developers to get creative and highlight what makes their projects one-of-a-kind.  So while gold could steal some Bitcoin's thunder in the short run, down the road it could find new ways to shine.I only think this is a fantasy. I mean the question that the OP asked. Gold standard means the currency of a nation would be in gold price. Each country will prefer to defend their currencies and they will not prefer the gold standard because this could likely have negative effect on their own currencies when than bitcoin. I do not think it will affect bitcoin at all even if it becomes true. But it is far more of fantasy than what could become reality.

comments.author: fuguebtc
comments.body: QuoteThe return of the Gold Standard.The problem is that scenario will never happen, the US government faced many difficulties in eliminating the gold standard so that it could freely print money and export inflation to the world. Therefore, their attempt to restore the gold standard will never happen. Besides, I don't think bringing back the gold standard would bring any good to our world. It is no different from a double-edged sword because the population is increasing, supply and demand are imbalanced, and if the Government cannot print money itself to solve this problem, the poor will also be larger, and they will continue to be more miserable. It can be said that maintaining world stability is not as simple as we think.Regarding bitcoin , I don't think there will be any impact because the scenario of the world returning to the gold standard will never happen.

comments.body: Quote from: Cryptomultiplier on July 28, 2024, 11:53:41 AMWill the return of the gold standard prompt the rise or fall of Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies acceptance in general? Be it to be used as payment method or choice for liquidating or diversification of assets?We are living in and moving toward a digital era and moving backwards to gold standard is against natural development of the world.The gold standard is very cumbersome and with convenience and more advantageous factors like security, privacy, and more, Bitcoin standard is better than gold standard. comments.body: You mentioned two factors that the coming of gold backed coin will take in the bitcoin market but then you did not outline enough points that could trigger a better discussions, since you did not specify just one dimension, you mentioned rise and also you mentioned falls which means both in upward and downward at the same time, so how then do you want us to contribute to this discussion on the gold backed coin and it effect on bitcoin.But for the record, just know that gold backed coins will only have his own space in the market and according to it supporters and how best the believe in the network, so definitely the coming of gold backed coins will not have any negative or positive reflection on bitcoin or the entire cryptocurrency market.

comments.author: Yatsan
comments.body: Quote from: Cryptomultiplier on July 28, 2024, 11:53:41 AMWill the return of the gold standard prompt the rise or fall of Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies acceptance in general? Be it to be used as payment method or choice for liquidating or diversification of assets?Your thoughts are welcomed!Return of gold standard could have mix effect on Bitcoin and Crypto. However, if gold leads to increased confidence and stability in fiat currency, the appeal of crypto or alternative assets might decline. Bitcoin and other crypto can be compared to as digital gold due to finite supply and potential as s store of value. If gold stabilized the global monetary system, it could restore dependence in fiat currencies and possibly limits the need for cryptocurrencies. Still cryptocurrencies offer benefits like fast and low-cost international transaction and financial involvement, which very unlikely to the policies of fiat currency so crypto's role might remain unaffected if gold standard shift's back.Quote from: dzungmobile on July 28, 2024, 02:47:14 PMThe world debt with combination of many national debts keep increasing sharply with time.Very timely, global debt increases dramatically because many countries are borrowing more money. It surge more during the COVID-19 pandemic as all government borrows money just to support their economies.

comments.author: retreat
comments.body: The return of the gold standard will not significantly affect Bitcoin, I mean you have seen how Bitcoin has grown quite significantly in the last few years, even when it was rejected by many parties and also governments, but it was still able to be adopted by more people globally. So the return of the gold standard will only disrupt fiat and banking, not Bitcoin, because Bitcoin itself already has its own users and the purpose of Bitcoin is clear to provide privacy and decentralization to people's transactions - as long as there are people who want that, then Bitcoin adoption will continue to increase.

comments.author: DaveF
comments.body: Returning to the gold standard would cause massive economic collapse. There is not enough gold out there to allow economies to function. The reshaping of how things are done to allow for it would cause so much pain that it could never work.Anyone who can do even basic math can figure it out.There are about 244,000 metric tons of gold in the world. A metric ton is 1000 kilograms so 244000*1000 so 244,000,000 kilograms there are 1000 grams in a kilogram so * 1000 again gets you 244,000,000,000 grams of gold. A gram of gold is worth at the moment $79 give or take. so 244,000,000,000 * 79 = $ 19,276,000,000,000 lets call it $20 trillion for round numbers. You can't run the world on $20 trillion available. Even if you multiply that by 100 you still can't.-Dave

comments.author: pinggoki
comments.body: Gold standard isn't a good way to buff up the economy and there's a reason why a lot of countries have abandoned such system in the first place, it can only work so far that you've got gold after all. Maybe it will give way to the price of bitcoin pumping up but the dollar will go down in value so basically, what happens is that you just have more dollar but the purchasing power of it is just not that big of a deal so there's really nothing gained from returning to gold standard, probably it's in your favor if you have a gold in your possession but other than that, I do believe that there's really nothing that you can gain for it in the long-term.
